infrastructure and operations at digital globe and rich rodolfo who is a senior director operations at Philips so the
really key and fundamental reason why we've done a series of launches in this space is that migrating large-scale data
turns out to be an incredibly challenging problem and we you know in my lure in my work as the GM of glacier
in particular and talking to customers who are trying to get data into later and into s3 this has been a recurring
theme for many many years for us will talk to customers and it ends up being a conversation not so much about what they're gonna do when they're actually
in the storage service though they're aiming to move to but how the heck they get there and you run into all sorts of problems when you try to do this at
scale so everything from the speed and cost of the transfer particularly for going over the network people tend to do
the calculation for how long it's going to take and what it's going to cost to get from A to B and then just look at that and basically decide that it's just
not feasible to go over the network once you're sort of over the point where you don't think you can go over a network you run into all sorts of
interesting problems of okay how else could I do it and typically you would go to maybe a shipping model where you're trying to ship bytes around but then you
immediately get into all sorts of problems with logistics and security how are you gonna get that much data from A to B and so we sort of took that as a
big challenge in my space and in the overall storage space for many years is how do we actually you know help
customers get data from A to B and this is what led us last year to launch the AWS snowball offering and so snowball
the first version of the snowball which we launched last year at reinvents was really going after that this problem how
do we ship data from A to B and by shipping it you really solve that that first those first two big problems of
speed and cost and then what we went after was okay well how do we handle the logistics and the security aspects of the problem and so what we decided to do
there was okay we decided to take the snowball the device itself turn it to its own case give it its own smart label
to really solve the problems of how you're getting the data form A to B how you're making sure sort of being tracked and and kept and
and sort of watched as it's being moved we added really strong encryption and to end through the process so we knew that
if the data was ever intercepted or device was lost or anything like that that that was a non-issue and nobody can get at your data and then we packed as
much storage and networking we could in a size and form factor that a single human could still lift and then you
could actually plug in a standard wall power and that was what we launched last year and just to give an overview of exactly how that works for for folks who
haven't seen it before it the essential workflow looks like this you'd go to our console you'd trade a job tell us an
address to ship the snow ball to we would then ship the snow ball to whatever address you told us you plug it
into your local power and network you then have a high throughput connection to that 50 terabyte device you'd load it
up with data once it's filled you unplug that our label automatically pops up on the e-ink label and then you'd ship it
back to us for high speed ingest at our region and that's been a really exciting first year for for snowball I've got to

customers data we've shut down data centers for customers and it's been really really exciting to see the uptake
we've shipped snowballs such that the equivalent of snowballs have traveled a
hundred times around the world we've also launched quite a few features over the year so we launched mid-year a

a new service like this is you launch it in them within a few days or weeks you realize ah this is what people are actually doing with it and one of the
big fun surprises for us was the number of people who wanted to move Hadoop workloads and so one of the things we
did in the client was add things like HDFS integration to somewhere to easily move those but the one of the other

Gration challenge what you have is you have a huge pile of data sitting in location a and you need to move said pile to location B and that's there's a

was a bit of a different view into what needed to be done in the world here so in this case in the data collection case
you don't have a big pile of existing data you're trying to move what you have is some source of data out there in the

turns out that that's actually a really hard problem and those customers were excited that we're helping us that we were able to help them with the last few

from whatever was emitting all that data that sort of source of that data they needed first to have somewhere to

you can't lose it so right so it can't be sort of beholden to like a single device or a single point of failure the
next thing that they typically had to do was they had to access that data now this could be in the form of a human wanting to get at it look at it do

per second port and a 40 gigabit per second port for faster transfers the other thing that we found was that
certain customers especially in cases we're doing things like trying to shut down data centers the client software

were able to fool all of that functionality onto the snowball itself have the snowballs securely perform all

which basically allows you to get an of snowballs and clustered together as a single durable storage pool the idea
